article.Heading: Budget 2017: Railways gets Rs 1.3 lakh cr outlay; IRCTC service charge waived
article.Summary: Announcing the setup of a rail safety corpus, Finance Minister Arun Jaitley in his Union Budget speech proposed to invest Rs 1.3 lakh crore in Indian Railways in the fiscal year 2017-18.
article.Body:
Chaitanya Gudipaty
Moneycontrol

Announcing the setup of a rail safety corpus, Finance Minister Arun Jaitley in his Union Budget speech proposed to invest Rs 1.3 lakh crore in Indian Railways in the fiscal year 2017-18. 

Jaitley said the Railway Ministry will set up a Rs 1 lakh-crore safety corpus — Rashtriya Rail Sanraksha Kosh.

The total outlined a capital expenditure of Rs 1.31 lakh crore will include Rs 51,000 crore from the government and will be used toward increasing operational efficiencies, building and upgrading railway crossings and over-bridges, among others, Jaitley said.

"Railway lines of 3,500 km will be commissioned in 2017-18, as against 2,800 kms in 2016-17. Steps will be taken to launch dedicated trains for tourism and pilgrimage," the Finance Minister said in his speech.

Besides, Jaitley said the service charge on e-tickets booked via IRCTC will be done away with, adding that cashless train ticket bookings had increased to 68%.

"Railways will offer competitive ticket booking facility to the public at large. Service charge on e-tickets booked through IRCTC has been withdrawn. Cashless reservations have gone up from 58% to 68%," Jaitley said.







In a first, the government set a unified Budget merging Railway and Union Budget. The Finance Minster's speech on railway budget spanned just 6 minutes, shrinking from 120 minutes in the past years.

Moneycontrol had last month reported that the government may impose a safety cess to fund the railway safety corpus. (Read here).

Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu had in December written to Jaitley seeking that the Centre fund the corpus entirely. The Finance Ministry, however, rejected the Railway Ministry’s proposal for financing of the new safety fund from the consolidated fund of India.

The Finance Ministry agreed to finance only 25 percent of the fund and has asked the Railways to raise the remaining three-fourths of the required sources for the special corpus.

A Railway Ministry-appointed committee has, in its report, envisaged works of track renewal and upgradation, bridge rehabilitation, elimination of level-crossings, construction of road over bridges/road under bridges, replacement and improvement of signalling system, among others.
